poem:
**Echoes of Ignored Warnings**

In valleys where the rain  
draws rivers from tears,  
nothing learned—floods  
whisper forgotten storms,  
inhabit houses and hearts.  
Water's language, relentless,  
scribes its mark upon  
the land's fragile pages  
that turn, sodden, yet  
tell the same sorrow:  
a cycle unbroken.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "‘No lessons have been learned’: as floods recede, anger rises in south Wales valleys After the anguish, came the anger. As flood waters subsided across the south Wales valleys and devastated residents and business owners surveyed the damage done by Storm Bert, questions were being asked about whether warnings were adequate. Many of the overwhelmed towns and villages experienced similar devastation in 2020 when Storm Dennis swept through – yet those interviewed by the Guardian". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
